articles.headline: Europe and the U.S. Make Ambitious Plans to Reduce Reliance on Russian Gas
articles.snippet: President Biden said the United States would send more natural gas to Europe, though he did not specify how given that the U.S. is already near its export capacity.
articles.abstract: President Biden said the United States would send more natural gas to Europe, though he did not specify how given that the U.S. is already near its export capacity.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States announced a deal with European leaders on Friday to increase shipments of natural gas to help wean Europe off Russian energy. And Germany set an ambitious goal of halving its imports of Russian oil and coal this year and freeing itself from its dependence on Russian natural gas by the middle of 2024.

articles.headline: Russia Signals Redefined Goals in Ukraine War as Its Advances Stall
articles.snippet: The Russian Defense Ministry suggested its forces would concentrate on securing the eastern part of Ukraine, where Kremlin-backed separatists have long been fighting.
articles.abstract: The Russian Defense Ministry suggested its forces would concentrate on securing the eastern part of Ukraine, where Kremlin-backed separatists have long been fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia signaled a possible recalibration of its war aims in Ukraine on Friday as the Kremlin faced spreading global ostracism for the brutal invasion, hardened Western economic punishments and a determined Ukrainian resistance that appeared to be making some gains on the ground.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Michael D. Shear and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Justice Thomas Ruled on Election Cases. Should His Wife’s Texts Have Stopped Him?
articles.snippet: The nature of the text messages was enough to require recusal, legal experts said. But the Supreme Court has traditionally left such decisions to the discretion of the justice in question.
articles.abstract: The nature of the text messages was enough to require recusal, legal experts said. But the Supreme Court has traditionally left such decisions to the discretion of the justice in question.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The disclosure that Virginia Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, had sent a barrage of text messages to the Trump White House urging efforts to overturn the 2020 election brought into sharp focus the conflict of interest her political activism has created — and the lack of a clear-cut remedy.

articles.headline: Streaming Took Over Hollywood. Will It Take Best Picture, Too?
articles.snippet: A few years ago, the entertainment industry was arguing over whether movies on streaming services even counted as a film. Now, one is poised to win the Oscars’ top prize.
articles.abstract: A few years ago, the entertainment industry was arguing over whether movies on streaming services even counted as a film. Now, one is poised to win the Oscars’ top prize.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Hollywood was engaged in a knock-down, drag-out fight over the future of cinema — what, exactly, constitutes a film — with the Oscars as the boxing ring.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: At the Edge of Kyiv, Ukrainians Show Off Their Counteroffensive
articles.snippet: Destroyed tanks and body parts are all that are left of a Russian advance, part of the larger battle to block the invaders’ attempt to enter or encircle the capital.
articles.abstract: Destroyed tanks and body parts are all that are left of a Russian advance, part of the larger battle to block the invaders’ attempt to enter or encircle the capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTHERN OUTSKIRTS OF KYIV, Ukraine — When Ukrainian forces hit a Russian tank with an American-made Javelin missile on a highway on the northern reaches of the capital, Kyiv, the explosion was so huge that it tossed the turret 10 yards down the road and shredded the rest of the vehicle and the men inside.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

articles.headline: In a Fiery Speech, Biden Warns of a Battle Between ‘Liberty and Repression’
articles.snippet: The president warned Western nations that the fight against autocracy would be costly and could be lengthy.
articles.abstract: The president warned Western nations that the fight against autocracy would be costly and could be lengthy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — President Biden delivered a forceful denunciation of Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine on Saturday, declaring “for God’s sake, this man cannot remain in power,” as he cast the war as the latest front in a decades-long battle between the forces of democracy and oppression.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: The Making of Vladimir Putin
articles.snippet: Tracing Putin’s 22-year slide from statesman to tyrant.
articles.abstract: Tracing Putin’s 22-year slide from statesman to tyrant.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Speaking in what he called “the language of Goethe, Schiller and Kant,” picked up during his time as a K.G.B. officer in Dresden, President Vladimir V. Putin addressed the German Parliament on Sept. 25, 2001. “Russia is a friendly European nation,” he declared. “Stable peace on the continent is a paramount goal for our nation.”

articles.headline: Texts Show Ginni Thomas’s Embrace of Conspiracy Theories
articles.snippet: In the aftermath of the 2020 presidential election, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas was involved in a range of efforts to keep President Donald J. Trump in power.
articles.abstract: In the aftermath of the 2020 presidential election, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas was involved in a range of efforts to keep President Donald J. Trump in power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two days after the 2020 election, Virginia Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, texted an old friend, Mark Meadows, the chief of staff to President Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim, Jo Becker and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: The True Crime-Obsessed Philanthropists Paying to Catch Killers
articles.snippet: When the police can’t afford to solve cold cases using DNA databases, deep-pocketed donors can.
articles.abstract: When the police can’t afford to solve cold cases using DNA databases, deep-pocketed donors can.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last January, Carla Davis was on LinkedIn when she saw an intriguing post: “Identify the Victim of 1978 Tennessee Murder.”

articles.headline: Chris Wallace Says Life at Fox News Became ‘Unsustainable’
articles.snippet: As he starts a new streaming show at CNN, the longtime TV anchor reflects on his decision to leave Fox News after 18 years.
articles.abstract: As he starts a new streaming show at CNN, the longtime TV anchor reflects on his decision to leave Fox News after 18 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I just no longer felt comfortable with the programming at Fox.”

articles.headline: With Eyes on Russia, the U.S. Military Prepares for an Arctic Future
articles.snippet: As climate change opens up the Arctic for transit and exploration, Russia has increasingly militarized the region. The U.S. is preparing a more aggressive presence of its own.
articles.abstract: As climate change opens up the Arctic for transit and exploration, Russia has increasingly militarized the region. The U.S. is preparing a more aggressive presence of its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: As the war in Ukraine moves into its second month, fears grow of Mariupol’s fall to Russia.
articles.snippet: Ukraine’s top military intelligence officer suggested that Russia was changing its military focus to the south and east and might be trying to divide the country.
articles.abstract: Ukraine’s top military intelligence officer suggested that Russia was changing its military focus to the south and east and might be trying to divide the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russian forces redoubled attacks on strategic targets across Ukraine on Sunday, with fierce fighting reported around the capital, Kyiv, amid signs that the besieged city of Mariupol was close to falling.

articles.headline: Zelensky Gives Interview to Russian Journalists. Moscow Orders It Quashed.
articles.snippet: The remarkable interview was still published by journalists outside of Russia, an episode that laid bare the extraordinary, and partly successful, efforts at censorship by Moscow.
articles.abstract: The remarkable interview was still published by journalists outside of Russia, an episode that laid bare the extraordinary, and partly successful, efforts at censorship by Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a remarkable moment in the war in Europe: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine gave a 90-minute-long Zoom interview on Sunday to four prominent journalists from Russia, the country invading his.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Onstage Slap Rattles Oscars, Before ‘CODA’ Triumphs
articles.snippet: On a night when “CODA” became the first film from a streaming service to win best picture, the focus was on Will Smith’s altercation with Chris Rock.
articles.abstract: On a night when “CODA” became the first film from a streaming service to win best picture, the focus was on Will Smith’s altercation with Chris Rock.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In an Academy Awards ceremony where an onstage altercation between Will Smith and Chris Rock overshadowed the honors, “CODA” from Apple TV+ won the Oscar for best picture, becoming the first film from a streaming service to be welcomed into that rarefied Hollywood club.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: Rumble, the Right’s Go-To Video Site, Has Much Bigger Ambitions
articles.snippet: The company, supported by Donald Trump, Peter Thiel and other prominent conservatives, wants to help build a “new internet” independent from Silicon Valley’s titans.
articles.abstract: The company, supported by Donald Trump, Peter Thiel and other prominent conservatives, wants to help build a “new internet” independent from Silicon Valley’s titans.
articles.lead_paragraph: You won’t find Red Pill News or the X22 Report on YouTube anymore. The far-right online shows were taken down in the fall of 2020 after the major social media and tech companies started purging accounts that spread the QAnon conspiracy theory.

articles.headline: When Nokia Pulled Out of Russia, a Vast Surveillance System Remained
articles.snippet: The Finnish company played a key role in enabling Russia’s cyberspying, documents show, raising questions of corporate responsibility.
articles.abstract: The Finnish company played a key role in enabling Russia’s cyberspying, documents show, raising questions of corporate responsibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nokia said this month that it would stop its sales in Russia and denounced the invasion of Ukraine. But the Finnish company didn’t mention what it was leaving behind: equipment and software connecting the government’s most powerful tool for digital surveillance to the nation’s largest telecommunications network.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Aaron Krolik

articles.headline: New Supply Chain Risk: 22,000 Dockworkers Who May Soon Strike
articles.snippet: With the contract of union workers at West Coast ports nearing expiration, the prospect of a labor impasse threatens another shock to the global economy.
articles.abstract: With the contract of union workers at West Coast ports nearing expiration, the prospect of a labor impasse threatens another shock to the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a world contending with no end of economic troubles, a fresh source of concern now looms: the prospect of a confrontation between union dockworkers and their employers at some of the most critical ports on earth.

articles.headline: Biden’s $5.8 Trillion Budget Pivots Toward Economic and Security Concerns
articles.snippet: The president released his latest budget proposal amid war in Ukraine and concerns at home about rising costs.
articles.abstract: The president released his latest budget proposal amid war in Ukraine and concerns at home about rising costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday proposed a $5.8 trillion budget that includes significant increases in funding for the military and police departments, along with higher taxes on corporations and the wealthiest Americans.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Alan Rappeport and Emily Cochrane
